awd_titl_txt: RUI: Testing QCD Symmetries via Precision Measurements of Light Pseudoscalar Mesons
awd_abstract_narration:
The Standard Model (SM) is a theory that describes fundamental particles in nature and the interactions between them.  While the SM has been successful in explaining many phenomena observed in the laboratory to date, it offers no insight into experimental facts such as the dominance of matter over anti-matter, nor the nature of dark matter and dark energy, which are associated with the rotation curves of the galaxies and the accelerated expansion of the universe. Searching for physics beyond the Standard Model is therefore a well-motivated and important task for physicists. A good way to search for new physics is through tests of fundamental symmetries in different interactions.

The goal of this project is to test fundamental symmetries in the electromagnetic and strong interactions via precision measurements on the properties of neutral particles: neutral pion and eta.  The radiative decay width of the neutral pion plays a key role that bridges chiral symmetry spontaneous breaking and our understanding of QCD (a theory describing the strong interaction).  On the other hand, the measurement of the eta radiative decay width will reveal the effect of explicit symmetry breakings of chiral symmetry, isospin, and SU(3)  by the light-quark masses. In addition, the measurements of branching ratios or upper limits for various rare and forbidden decays of the eta will provide sensitive probes to test the violations of charge conjugation C, parity P, and time reversal T, as well as CP symmetries, and search for new physics beyond the Standard Model. The results of this project will provide clues to some important questions, such as: "why is our observed universe dominated by matter over anti-matter?", and "what are the masses of the light quarks?"

This project will engage undergraduate students as key contributors. It will create a research-enriched learning environment, explore new approaches to recruiting prospective students, and develop new courses which are research related.  Students working in an international collaboration will enhance their international experience and gain global perspectives.

por.por_cntn:
The frontier of contemporary physics is to understand the confinement properties of the Quantum Chromo-Dynamics (QCD) and to search for new physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) of the particle physics. The decays of three neutral pseudoscalar mesons π0, η and η′ offer sensitive hadronic probes to address both fundamental challenges.  The π0 and η mesons are Goldstone Bosons induced by spontaneous chiral symmetry breaking, while η′ is not due to the chiral anomaly. This system contains fundamental information about the effects of SU(3) and isospin symmetry breaking by the quark masses, leading to important mixing among the mesons. The precision measurements of both static and dynamic properties of these mesons in the two-photon fusion interaction will provide sensitive probes for the symmetry structure of QCD at low energy. In addition, these mesons are rare eigenstates of the charge conjugation ( C ) in the nature, in addition to P, CP, and G, making them natural candidates to test the discrete symmetries. Particularly, η has a relatively long lifetime with its strong and electromagnetic decays being either anomalous or forbidden at the leading order due to P, C, CP, G-parity and angular momentum conservation. This enhances the relative importance of higher order contributions, making the rare η decays a sensitive hadronic probe for weakly-coupled new forces, such as a dark force via a leptophobic dark vector boson or a new C-violating, P-conserving force. The measurements of light pseudoscalar meson rare decays at the high intensity facilities, such as Jefferson Lab (JLab), will be complementary to the high energy frontier for the searches of the new physics beyond SM.

With the support from this award, PI has been leading the PrimEx collaboration in a precision measurement of   the two-photon decay width of π0, called as radiative decay width. The preliminary results from two independent analyses for the second experiment (PrimEx-II) data have shown that our experimental precision for the π0 radiative decay width has reached better than 2%, which would be the most precise measurement of this fundamental parameter in the world. It will provide a stringent test on the chiral anomaly and the confinement QCD predictions.  A new measurement of the η radiative decay width is underway, where PI is a co-spokesperson. This experiment passed the JLab readiness review in summer 2017 and will be ready for taking date in one year. This is a highly anticipated experiment to improve all η decay widths in the particle data group listing that will have a broad impact. It will offer a crucial input for model independent determinations of the light quark mass ratio and the η-η' mixing angle. Under the leadership of PI, the JLab Eta Factory (JEF) experiment on the rare η decays has been developed in the past a few years and received a full approval from JLab Program Advisory Committee (PAC) in July 2017. It will offer a unique probe for new physics beyond the Standard Model by searching for a leptophobic vector B’, an electrophobic scalar Φ’, and the C-violating, P-conserving new forces. The results from this experiment will have potential to shield light on the puzzles of the proton charge radius, the mystery of the dark matter, and the asymmetry of matter-antimatter in the universe.

This project also provided excellent opportunities for training young physicists and undergraduate students. Eleven UNCW physics major students had directly worked on this project and spent at least two months at Jefferson Lab in the summer.  Two students wrote honor’s theses based on their research results related to this project. Involvement of students in research also lead student presentations at the university and several national conferences.  In addition, working in the international collaborations  offered students opportunities to gain global perspectives. In addition, two young visiting scholars from China worked on this project for 1-2 years. A visiting Ph.D. student from Lanzhou University, China, worked on the PrimEx-II data analysis as her Ph.D. thesis subject.
